THE GAME v0.5.1d
THeory of Evidence in a lanGuage Adapted for Many Embedded systems

Version notes

V0.2

New operations are now available:

  • discounting() : This function corresponds to the classical discounting operation. The lost belief is transferred on the complete universe.
  • *Combination() and full*Combination() : These functions implements the different combination rules proposed in the belief functions framework Two functions have been modified: combination() and fullCombination(). They now take an argument concerning the type of combination rule to use.

V0.3

Name of operations have been corrected. The implementation of sets has been optimized a lot (exec time divided by 2 and a lot of memory saved). The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !

V0.3.1

An emulation of namespace has been added in modules for function names. Minor bugs have been corrected.

V0.3.2

The pure BFT has been separated from the application with sensors. Thus, the belief building from sensor measures has been put in a new specific file called BeliefsFromSensors(.h and .c).

V0.4

New functionalities:

  • Options: It is now possible to add options to the belief model adding a file called 'options' with the files containing the points for sets of belief functions. The file should contain one option per line composed of a name of option and a float parameter. Only variation and tempo are now available.
  • Decision support functions: those functions implemented in BeliefFunctions module enable to find a max or a min of a belief function for mass, belief and plausibility. The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !

V0.4.1

Correction of the function used to measure time in the tempo option. (Use of clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME,...) now)
Adding Sets_elementToBitString() in Sets module.
Adding the DEBUG, CHECK_SUM and CHECK_VALUES defines in config.h to customize the compilation and optimize a little more the execution time.
The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !

V0.4.2

Adding Sets_elementFromNumber() and Sets_numberFromElement() in Sets module.
Correction of a bug in the function Sets_elementToBitString().
Addition of a function Sets_setToBitString().
Separation of the temporization in a new function BFS_temporization() instead of doing it directly in BFS_getProjection().
Code of the function BFS_getProjection() cleaned up.
In BFS_getProjection(), if sensorMeasure == WEIRD_NUMBER, then the projection equals the vacuous belief function. The temporization is done anyway. It's really usefull if you replace a lost measure by this WEIRD_NUMBER because you'll get the vacuous or a trace of the last belief using the temporization.
The BeliefFunctions module has been cleaned of all the "elementSize" by putting this variable inside the BF_BeliefFunction structure.
Diverse things have been renamed to be more explicit and/or more convenient for the extension of the library.
The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !

V0.5

Addition of a new applicative module BeliefsFromBeliefs.
Minor changes in diverse modules (that's the spirit of uncertain modification :)).
Addition of a new function to clean the BF_BeliefFunction of non-focal elements.
Addition of a new way of doing temporization using Dubois & Prade's combination rule instead of a discrimination based on specificity.
In the module BeliefsFromSensors, the options are now managed using flags, thus it should be easier to add and manage new options!
The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !

V0.5.1

Addition of a new function to normalize the BF_BeliefFunctions.
Addition of a new applicative module BeliefsFromRandomness (in progress...)
Some things have been renamed to be more explicit.
No more warnings! (compiling well with -Wall -Wextra -Werror -pedantic)
In BeliefsFromSensors.h, a new define has been added to enable the use of different clocks for the temporization. It is useful when working on diverse OS implementing different clocks.
Some combination rules have been reimplemented to increase performance and this is much better ! (I got rid of the dirty code of the beginning of the project...)
The implementation is totally mem-check free (checked with Valgrind) !
